messageBody:
--- David Brady <junit_list@s...> wrote:
> 1. Is there a good way to catch command-line args when
> running JUnit?

To configure subsets of tests to run (and not), I've used a properties
or XML configuration file. My defaults are to run all the tests, but
during development, I "hijack" the file (setting it writable outside
the source code management system), and turn off the very long running
tests. I control which tests run by inheriting from abstract base
classes I wrote that themselves extend TestCase (in JUnit 3.x). I
override the constructor, to mark the test method names for classes
where I'm not running the tests. (And given the way that Java
constructors work, this makes me put this customization logic in a
static method called by the constructor.) It takes a little program
logic to be able to consistently find the properties/configuration
files in all the different environments in which our JUnit tests run
(ant, and several different IDEs); default directory settings are not
standardized.
